questions.text: Based on histopathological examination of benign breast tissue, which of the following has the lowest relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Squamous metaplasia on histopathological examination of benign breast tissue has the lowest risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma.

According to the American College of Pathologists Consensus Statement, relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on pathological examination of benign breast tissue is as follows:

No increased risk :

  1. Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
  2. Apocrine metaplasia
  3. Cysts, macro and/or micro
  4. Duct ectasia
  5. Fibroadenoma
  6. Fibrosis
  7. Hyperplasia
  8. Mastitis (inflammation)
  9. Periductal mastitis
  10. Squamous metaplasia

Slightly increased risk (1.5–2 times):

  • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid or papillary (Option B)
  • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core (Option C)

Moderately increased risk (5 times):

  • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular) (Option A)

Insufficient data to assign a risk:

  • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
  • Radial scar lesion

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes,  dry mouth, and difficulty in swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of parotid glands. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. She is at high risk for developing  ______.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing solid food, and the findings such as enlarged parotid gland, and antibodies positive for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren's syndrome. The histopathology shows focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the salivary gland. She is at high risk for the development of marginal zone lymphoma.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can manifest as primary or secondary. Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50-60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens -SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. 

Patients are at high risk for the development of marginal zone lymphoma that arises in the presence of chronic lymphocytic inflammation.

Other options -

Option A: Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma - It is observed in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is characterized by skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia. Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells). It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Option B: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It is more common in middle-aged men and people with darker skin. MF may present as dermatitis or eczema for a few years before progressing to the classical presentation of patches and plaques as shown in the image above. The most common sites involved are the trunk, limbs, breasts, and buttocks. The lesions may present with pruritus or be asymptomatic. As it progresses, the patient may develop, ulceration and pain or even widespread erythroderma. 

Option C: Sezary syndrome is most often seen as a progression of mycosis fungoides. Sezary syndrome is defined by the following clinical triad:

  • Erythroderma
  • Peripheral lymphadenopathy
  • Atypical circulating mononuclear cells

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast-enhanced MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to the excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. This syndrome is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. The excess serotonin produced is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA.  

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Given below is the image showing an X-ray finding of a bone tumor. Which of the following is the true statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Metaphysis of distal femur is a common location
Diaphysis of humerus is the most common location

questions.solution:
The given image shows a lateral radiograph of the tibia demonstrating the lamellated periosteal reaction in the diaphysis suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma. The true statement regarding this condition is that it is a highly radiosensitive tumor.

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis.

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round blue cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes (shown in the image given below). Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH) demonstrates a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. In the image given below, the fused region denoted by yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance. 

Since Ewing's sarcoma is a highly radio-sensitive tumor. It is treated with combined radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age
Simple bone cyst Proximal Humeral Metaphysis <20years
Enchondroma

Hand bones

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

Osteochondroma

(Exostosis)

 Distal Femoral Metaphysis <18years
Osteoid osteoma Diaphysis of Femur

2nd & 3rd

decade
Osteoblastoma Posterior column of vertebra

2nd & 3rd

decade

Osteoclastoma (GCT)

 Distal femoral epiphysis

2nd -4th

Decade
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst Long bone Metaphysis <18years
Osteosarcoma Distal Femoral Metaphysis

BIMODAL

Primary- 2nd Decade Secondary-6th and 7th Decade
Ewings sarcoma Diaphysis of Femur 5-25 years
Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade
Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

 

Related Pearl: Most common sites of primary bone tumors

EPIPHYSEAL :

  • Chondroblastoma 
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Articular osteochondroma (trevor’s disease)
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma 

DIAPHYSEAL:

  • Round cell lesions-Ewing’s sarcoma 
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Histiocytosis
  • Osteoblastoma

METAPHYSEAL:

  • Chondrosarcoma (Note:Clear cell chondrosarcoma is epiphyseal)
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with an abdominal mass. After laparotomy, the mass demonstrates a cystic cavity filled with hair, sebaceous material, cartilage, bone, along with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage. On microscopic examination, varying amounts of the immature neuroepithelium,  cartilage,  bone,  muscle,  and other elements are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is consistent with immature teratoma.

Immature malignant teratomas:

  • The tumor is found chiefly in prepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years.
  • The component tissues resemble embryonal and immature fetal tissue most, often consisting of primitive neuroepithelium on histological examination. On microscopic examination, there are varying amounts of the immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, muscle, and other elements.
  • The histologic grade of the tumor, based on the proportion of tissue containing immature neuroepithelium indicates risk for extra-ovarian spread.
  • High-grade tumours confined to the ovaries are treated with prophylactic chemotherapy.

Mature (Benign) teratoma(Option B):

  • Cystic teratomas are usually found in young women during the active reproductive years. 
  • They are bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases.
  • They are unilocular cysts containing hair and sebaceous material sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue.
  • Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures.
  • About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma, but also to other cancers as well (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma).

Monodermal or specialized teratomas:

  • Struma ovarii (Option C) is composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and cause hyperthyroidism.
  • Ovarian carcinoid (Option D), which presumably arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional and causes carcinoid syndrome in the absence of hepatic metastasis.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of VIPoma.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumors (VIPomas) are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). The condition is known as Verner–Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome.

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhoea.

Treatment includes correction of dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte losses with fluid and electrolyte replacement. Long-acting somatostatin analogues such as octreotide and lanreotide are the drug of choice.

 

 

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient had complaints of post-coital bleeding with leucorrhoea. An initial visual inspection with acetic acid showed an abnormal finding, which, when followed by a colposcopic guided biopsy of the cervix,  had the malignant cells occupying the lower 50% to 75% of the epithelial thickness. She wishes for conservative treatment, as she has not completed her family. Which of the following might be offered considering the future pregnancy?

choices.text: Needle excision of the transformation zone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histologic finding are suggestive of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL/CIN II) of the cervix. An ideal procedure to be performed in this patient, anticipating the future pregnancy would be laser ablation.

This is because ablative techniques do not result in future pregnancy complications.

Techniques involving the excision of abnormal tissue such as

  • Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LLETZ)
  • Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP)
  • Needle Excision of the Transformation Zone (NETZ)
  • Cold knife conization
  • Laser conization

result in the stenosis of the cervix, abortion, and premature labour. Hence avoid in female patients who desire for childbirth in the near future

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented with multiple slow-growing nodules on the scalp.  A biopsy was taken and the histopathological examination revealed a jigsaw puzzle architecture as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with multiple slow-growing nodules in the scalp and with a 'jigsaw puzzle' appearance on histopathology points toward the diagnosis of cylindromas.

Cylindroma is an appendage tumour with ductal (apocrine or eccrine) differentiation inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to mutation of the CYLD gene. 

Patients present with multiple smooth, firm, pink to red coloured nodules on the forehead and scalp which may or may not be pedunculated. Nodules can coalesce and produce a hatlike growth which gives the name, turban tumour.

Histopathology shows lobules of epithelial cells arranged in a jigsaw or mosaic pattern. Each lobule is composed of islands of basaloid cells in the periphery and a paler zone of cells in the centre.

It is treated with wide excision and replacement of the area by a graft.

Other options:

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive skin malignancy occurring in sun-exposed areas in elderly individuals. Histology shows peripheral palisading of tumour cells which resemble normal cells of the basal cell layer of the epidermis.

Spiradenoma is a benign tumour of the sweat gland presenting as a solitary, painful bluish dermal nodule. Histology shows lobules containing larger pale cells around the lumina and smaller darker cells at the periphery, with intervening cystic spaces and vascular channels.

Merkel cell carcinoma is a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumour of the skin which presents as a smooth reddish round tumour. Histology shows cell nests and trabecular patterns and is often referred to as trabecular carcinoma of the skin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the hospital with complaints of hip pain and back pain. X-ray shows the following findings. Biopsy from the lesions confirms the diagnosis of metastatic secondaries. Which of the following is a likely source of metastasis?
questions.solution:
The patient's x-ray findings and clinical features are suggestive of osteoblastic secondaries, which are predominantly seen in prostate carcinoma.

Metastatic tumors are the most common form of skeletal malignancy, greatly outnumbering primary bone cancers.

Skeletal metastases are typically multifocal. However, carcinomas of the kidney and thyroid may present with solitary lesions. Most metastases involve the axial skeleton (vertebral column, pelvis, ribs, skull, and sternum). The red marrow in these areas, with its rich capillary network and slow blood flow, facilitates the implantation and growth of the tumor cells.

The radiographic appearance of metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Furthermore, some cancers are associated with predominantly one pattern or the other.

For example, prostatic adenocarcinoma is predominantly blastic, whereas malignant melanoma and carcinomas of the kidney, lung, and gastrointestinal tract produce lytic lesions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of the tumor specimen is shown in the below image. This finding indicates which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The given image shows signet ring cells which are seen in Kruckenberg tumors.

Krukenberg tumors are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis.
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

Other options:

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma, characterized by the arrangement of large tumor cells in bunches. Lymphocytes and giant cells are seen in between the tumor cells. Infiltration of fibrous septa by lymphocytes is an important diagnostic feature.

 


Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor, which is used as a tumor marker. 

Grossly these tumors appear as yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. Microscopically, these tumors show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are seen as papillary projections composed of a central core of blood vessels and are lined by tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

 

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-containing epithelial ovarian tumor. These tumors are usually multilocular and are lined by single columnar epithelium. They are usually unilateral and are found along with a dermoid cyst or a Brenner tumor. Grossly they have a glistening surface, and the cut section reveals multiple loculi filled with mucinous contents. If the tumour ruptures, it may lead to formation of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text:
Match the following features with their corresponding syndromes

 

Features Syndrome
A. Pheochromocytomas, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, parathyroid hyperplasia 1. MEN 1
B. Parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor, testicular tumor 2. MEN 2A

C. Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

 3. MEN 2B
D. Hyperparathyroidism, gastrinomas, prolactinomas  4. MEN 4
questions.solution:
The correct matched option is A-2, B-4, C-3, and D-1.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic. 

MEN 1 is a syndrome complex associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A comprises mainly medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B/3 consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A  researcher focussing on genodermatology was studying the harmful effect of UV radiation on human skin. He observed that UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA  polymerase. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms corrects this particular defect?
questions.solution:
The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA.

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Frontal image of the face, showing large hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection are evident.

 

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair, leading to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As time passes these lesions become permanent. As the age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. Since deeper structures like eyelids, cornea, and lens are shielded, are lesser affected.

XP is ultimately fatal. Early detection of skin lesions and their management (prevention of exposure to UV rays) prolongs life. 

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in tumor lysis syndrome?
  1. Hyperuricemia
  2. Hyperkalemia
  3. Hypokalemia
  4. Hyperphosphatemia
  5. Hypocalcemia
  6. Hypercalcemia
questions.solution:
The correct option is option C: 1, 2, 4, and 5. Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia occur in tumor lysis syndrome.

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

TLS is characterized by

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes aggressive hydration along with allopurinol. Febuxostat a selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, and rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase can be used to treat hyperuricemia. Hypocalcemia is not treated unless it is symptomatic, to avoid metastatic calcifications. Patients with renal impairment are managed with hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with lethargy, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. A  hematological malignancy was suspected. A peripheral smear showed cells positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase. Identify the correct CD marker and the cell of origin of this malignancy.
questions.solution:
Hematological malignancy with tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase-positive cells is most likely to be hairy cell leukemia. The cell of origin of hairy cell leukemia is the memory B cell. 

The markers expressed in hairy cell leukemia include the usual B-cell markers- CD-19 and 20, and specific markers such as CD 11c, CD 25, CD103, and annexin A1.

Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. These cells are called so because of the fine hair-like projections on their surface as shown below.

On peripheral blood smear, hairy cells have round or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with thread or bleb-like extension. In the bone marrow, these cells are usually trapped in a mesh of reticulin fibers and so it is difficult to aspirate and hence termed a dry tap. 

The classic hairy cells can be seen in the slide is shown below:

 

Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. There can be atypical monocytopenia due to which these patients experience an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

Other options:

Options A and D: CD 3 and CD 5 are markers of T cells.

Option C: Naive B cell is the cell of origin of mantle cell lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Antigen Designation and their Normal Cellular Distribution 
Primarily T-Cell Associated 
  • CD1 Thymocytes and Langerhans cells 
  • CD3 Thymocytes, mature T cells 
  • CD4 Helper T cells, subset of thymocytes  
  • CD5 T cells and a small subset of B cells  
  • CD8 Cytotoxic T cells, subset of thymocytes, and some NK cells 
Primarily B-Cell Associated 
  • CD10 Pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells 
  • CD19 Pre-B cells and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD20 Pre-B cells after CD19 and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD21 EBV receptor; mature B cells and follicular dendritic cells
  • CD23 Activated mature B cells 
  • CD79a Marrow pre-B cells and mature B cells 
Primarily Monocyte or Macrophage Associated 
  • CD11c Granulocytes, monocytes, and macrophages; also expressed by hairy cell leukemias 
  • CD13 Immature and mature monocytes and granulocytes 
  • CD14 Monocytes 
  • CD15 Granulocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants
  • CD33 Myeloid progenitors and monocytes  
  • CD64 Mature myeloid cells  
Primarily NK-CellAssociated 
  • CD16 NK cells and granulocytes  
  • CD56 NK cells and a subset of T cells 
Primarily Stem Cell and Progenitor Cell Associated  
  • CD34 Pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages 
Activation Markers 
  • CD30 Activated B cells, T cells, and monocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants 
Present on All Leukocytes 
  • CD45 All leukocytes; also known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA)

questions.text: A patient who has been under treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia is noted to have a rapidly progressing mass involving the spleen. Histopathology of the mass shows large cell lymphocytes with a diffuse pattern of growth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a rapidly progressing tumor involving the spleen in a patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and showing large cell lymphocytes on histopathology suggests a likely diagnosis of Richter syndrome.

Richter syndrome refers to the transformation of CLL into a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). There is a development of rapidly enlarging mass that involves a lymph node or spleen. It is an aggressive tumor and most patients with the syndrome survive less than a year.

DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is characteristically of large cell type and shows a diffuse pattern of growth. The most frequent pathological abnormality seen is dysregulation of BCL6.

Mature B-cell tumors express CD19 and CD20 markers. Special subtypes of DLBCL include immunodeficiency-assosciated large B-cell lymphoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

 

Other options:

Option A: Kostmann syndrome is a form of congenital neutropenia caused by genetic mutation that leads to impaired granulocytic differentiation. 

Option B: Mantle cell lymphoma is a non-hodgkin lymphoma that presents at fifth or sixth decade and has male predominance. Clinically, there is painless lymphadenopathy and can involve spleen and gut. Morphologically, there is proliferation of small lymphocytes with irregular nuclear contours.

Option D: Burkitt lymphoma can include endemic, sporadic, and lymphoma asssociated with HIV. Almost all endemic Burkitt lymphomas are latently infected with EBV. Clinically, it presents as a mass involving the mandible or abdominal viscera. Histopathologically, the tumor has high mitotic index and contains multiple apoptotic cells. The nucelar remnants are phagocytosed by benign macrophages which give a characteristic starry sky appearance.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of discoloration on her face. An excisional biopsy was done, and histopathology findings are shown below. They stain positive for HMB - 45. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Superficial spreading type is the most common variant
Mutation in the hedgehog signalling pathway
Mutation in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling pathway
Shows positive immunohistochemistry staining for S-100

questions.solution:
The given history and histopathology showing dense intracytoplasmic brownish-black melanin pigment are suggestive of malignant melanoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are associated with basal cell carcinoma and not malignant melanoma. 

Malignant melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction but may also originate from mucosal surfaces of the oropharynx, nasopharynx, eyes, proximal esophagus, anorectal, and female genitalia. It includes a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled. Amelanotic lesions appear as raised pink, purple, or flesh-colored skin papules. The diagnostic clue for melanoma is the ABCDE criteria.

It consists of

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variegation
  • Diameter of more than 6 mm 
  • Evolution or change

The image below shows a case of malignant melanoma.

Lentigo maligna, superficial spreading, acral lentiginous, and nodular are the variants of malignant melanoma. Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant (Option A) of malignant melanoma. It is more commonly seen on the trunk and proximal extremities. It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus after a chronic period of change in color and border. Mutations in cell cycle regulators, receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (Option C), and those that activate telomerase are associated with melanomas.

Markers for melanoma include:

  • S100 (Option D)
  • MELAN-A
  • HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: A 51-year-old female patient, Mrs. Susheela presents to dermatology OPD with a rash as seen in the image below. On further inquiry, she reveals that she has unintentionally lost a lot of weight over the past few months. Medical history is significant for a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she is being treated with T. Metformin 500mg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts necrolytic migrating erythema. This along with the clinical presentation is strongly suggestive of a glucagonoma. 

Glucagonoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, a majority of which are malignant at the time of presentation. They are most commonly seen arising from the pancreatic tail.

Clinically, the classic presentation of glucagonoma is with the “4 D’s”-

  • Diabetes
  • Dermatitis- A characteristic waxing and waning necrolytic migrating erythema is seen that usually appears before other symptoms.
  • Deep vein thrombosis 
  • Depression.

Diagnosis is established by estimating plasma glucagon levels. A level >1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic (normal plasma glucagon level is <150 pg/mL). Hypoaminoacidemia is also a characteristic laboratory finding. 

Treatment may include long-acting somatostatin analogues like octreotide to alleviate some of the clinical symptoms such as dermatitis. Surgical resection may be attempted but is often unsuccessful due to extrapancreatic malignant spread at the time of diagnosis. 

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient was suspected to have a seminoma of the testis. The mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. Which among the following findings is most likely to be seen microscopically?

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
Microscopically, seminomas show a fried egg appearance of cells. This refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (around 50% of GCTs). It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. It is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells.

Option D: Derivatives of all three germ layers- islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

 

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a headache for 8 months. MRI brain shows a right sub-frontal mass. The biopsy of the tumor specimen is given below. Which of the following statements are true regarding her condition?

choices.text: These tumours express hormone receptors like progesterone receptors
They are most commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1
They are predominantly known to be malignant tumours
Histopathological examination shows fried egg appearance

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of headache and histopathology showing the syncytial or whorled clusters of epithelial tumor cells is highly suggestive of meningioma. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors such as progesterone receptors. 

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors (Option C), usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2 (Option B), which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas.

They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. The most common karyotypic abnormality is the loss of the long arm of chromosome 22. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors (eg: Progesterone), hence, they may grow rapidly in pregnancy.

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. 

The tumor spreads in a sheet-like manner along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcifications. 

Grades of meningioma based on histologic subtypes by WHO are:

Grade I is the benign meningioma that has a relatively low risk of recurrence or aggressive growth. The histologic patterns are:

  • Meningothelial or syncytial (most common). They are clusters of epitheliod tumor cells that sit in tight groups without visible cell membranes as shown below.
  • Fibroblastic
  • Transitional
  • Psammomatous

The image below shows meningothelial or syncytial pattern:

Grade II is the atypical meningioma which has a high recurrence rate and more aggressive local growth. Histologic patterns are clear cell and chordoid. 

Grade III is the anaplastic or malignant meningioma is highly aggressive often resembling carcinoma or sarcoma. Histologic patterns are papillary and rhabdoid.

The image below shows a well-defined, hyper-intense, and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline suggestive of meningioma.

When the meningiomas are small and asymptomatic, observation with serial MRI studies is done. When larger and symptomatic, they should be excised. External beam radiotherapy is done for unresectable tumors.

Option D: Fried-egg appearance is seen in sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm in oligodendrogliomas.

 

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Classification and WHO Grading of Brain tumors

Related Pearl: Named Cells in Histopathology

Named cells

Condition

Anitschkow or caterpillar cells

Rheumatic heart disease

Globoid cells

Small cell carcinoma of lung

Crumpled tissue paper macrophages

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with a 2 cm thyroid nodule. A fine needle aspiration biopsy of the nodule revealed the findings given below in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: They usually appear as cold masses on thyroid scan
BRAF gain-of-function mutation is commonly associated
Lateral aberrant thyroid is managed with modified radical neck dissection
It is a predominant thyroid cancer in iodine-deficient areas

questions.solution:
The biopsy specimen shows grooved and crowded nuclei, with a clear, ground-glass appearance (Orphan Annie eye nuclei), which is a diagnostic feature of Papillary thyroid carcinoma. It is the most predominant thyroid cancer in iodine-sufficient areas. The most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient areas is follicular carcinoma.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer. It is also the most predominant thyroid cancer in children and iodine-sufficient areas. Radiation exposure is an important risk factor. 

Genetics:  

  • BRAF gain-of-function mutation (V600E amino acid substitution) is commonly associated (Option B)
  • RET/PTC rearrangements
  • NTRK gene fusions

The clinical features of Papillary thyroid carcinoma are as follows:

  • It is more common in females
  • The mean age of presentation is 30-40 years
  • Most patients are euthyroid, with painless swelling. Initial presentation may be with cervical lymphadenopathy due to lymph node metastases
  • These are usually multifocal (85% cases)
  • They appear as cold masses on thyroid scan (Option A)
  • Metastasis occurs via the lymphatic route

Skip metastasis from papillary thyroid carcinoma to the ipsilateral cervical lymph nodes, known as lateral aberrant thyroid, is managed with modified radical neck dissection. (Option C)

 Microscopic examination shows:

  • Presence of branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
  • Nuclei are clear with chromatin margination (empty appearing), known as Orphan Annie eye nuclei
  • Presence of intranuclear inclusions. These are “pseudo-inclusions” due to invagination of cytoplasm
  • Concentric calcified structures known as psammoma bodies are usually seen

The nuclear features are diagnostic of papillary carcinoma, even in the absence of typical papillary architecture. The histopathology image of papillary thyroid carcinoma is shown below:

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

Type of Thyroid Carcinoma  Mutations
Papillary Carcinoma

BRAF mutation

RET/PTC rearrangement

MET

NTRK1 fusion gene

GDNF - glial derived neurotropic factor
Follicular carcinoma  

RAS mutation

PIK3CA mutation

PTEN mutation

PAX8/PPAR1 fusion gene
Medullary carcinoma  RET mutation
Follicular adenoma  

TSH-R mutation

Gsα (GNAS) mutation

Ras mutation (<20% cases)

PAX8/PPARγ1 fusion (<10% cases)

PTEN
 Anaplastic carcinoma  

CTNNB1 (β-catenin)

TP53 inactivation

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

 

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.
